This garden market product is becoming more and more difficult to find otherwise impossible already from the month of November where starts the dry season and water became very rare. During that period, life in this couple became pitiful. The husband does not have any other job than the small subsistence agriculture and leave almost all the family charge between the hands of the woman. Although she is illiterate, Madam V. has always showed the proof of a rigorous management and good morality. That is a lot noticed in her first three credits obtained which were repaid without incident. Today, she is requesting a credit of $850 to buy a motor-pump in order to mastery the water and to continue to progress in her activities especially those of the counter season (dry season). This project will be very profitable, not only for her alone, but for the other women of her locality.

Madame V. Yawa née vers 1970 à Fidokpui dans le canton de Togblé. Elle est mariée et mère de cinq (05) enfants et a un autre enfant à sa charge. Elle vit à Fidokpui avec toute sa famille où elle a comme activité principale la culture et la vente de légumes (Adémé, Gboma, et Gombo) seule source de revenu de la famille. Cette culture maraîchère devient difficile sinon impossible déjà à partir du mois de Novembre où commence la saison sèche et l’eau de vient très rare. Au cours de cette période, la vie dans ce foyer devient plus pitoyable. Le mari n’a pas autre emploi que la petite agriculture de subsistance et laisse presque toute la charge du foyer entre les mains de la femme. Bien qu’analphabète, Madame V. Yawa a toujours fait preuve d’une gestion rigoureuse et d’une bonne moralité. Cela s’est beaucoup ressenti dans ses trois premiers obtenus et remboursés sans incident. Aujourd’hui, elle sollicite un crédit de $ 850 pour s’acheter une moto pompe afin de maîtriser l’eau et de pouvoir évoluer dans ses activités surtout de contre saison. Ce projet sera très bénéfique, non seulement pour elle seule, mais à d’autres femmes de sa localité.

loans.use: to buy a motor-pump and fertilizers

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en:
Douglas Y. is 41 years old and is living with HIV within the Kibera slums. He is also a widower. He has three children and also takes care of three orphans who were left in his care by his brother who died due to HIV related complications.    

In the year 2004, Douglas was privileged to go through two days training on local manufacture of detergents and shampoo, which was conducted by the Methodist Church in Kibera. The training showed how and where to get the ingredients for detergent and shampoo making.  

Douglas got $5 grant in kind from a friend, which he used to buy the ingredients he needed. He was able to make 20 litres of the detergent. He packed and sold this in plastic containers of 250 and 500 grams that he had collected from a nearby bar within Kibera for $1.50. He also decided to give samples of the detergent he had made to the neighboring organizations, schools and churches in order to advertise his products. It is now two years since he started selling the detergents and shampoo at Fort Jesus, Kibera. He has a wider market, ranging from his neighbors, the schools and churches within Kibera.

Douglas uses a wooden stick and plastic containers (basins) to mix his ingredients. He produces 80 litres of the detergent and shampoo in a week and sells in small quantities. He packs in containers of 20, 10 and 5 litres which he sells to his clients in schools, churches and organizations. He also packs in containers of 100 – 500 grams that he sells at an affordable price ($1.50) to his neighbors. He usually stores the little amount that remains in the plastic containers that he uses to mix the ingredients because of the shortage of storage containers.  

Douglas sees that his business is expanding and has a wider market. Given the loan of $ 75, he plans to purchase 30 plastic containers of 20 litres each to enable him store and pack his detergents and shampoo. Douglas has recently been approached by a group of women and youth who have been sponsored by a health clinic within the Kibera slums, to teach them on the process of making the detergent and shampoo. Douglas sees this as a move that will not only increase his income but also positively impact his community, which is characterized by idleness especially among the youth. Douglas also plans to transfer this skill to his children.  The loan is repayable within 6 – 12 months.

loans.use: To purchase plastic containers for storage of detergent

loans.name: Kosio

texts.en: Kosio K. is a carpenter. He worked for a private company for two years but then decided to start own business. Six years ago he opened a small carpentry workshop in the town of Alphatar, near Silistra. His business grows every year, and now Kosio provides employment to more than 10 people in the town. Finished goods are exported mainly to Italy. Kosio K. is single and lives with his parents. He is asking for a $1200 loan to buy a special cutting machine.

loans.use: To buy a special cutting machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her inventory of clothes and shoes

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
In 1998, M. Milly decided to start up a retail shop near her home in Kyebando, near Kampala city. The business started very well, but she had a limited stock while the demand for household items was high.

After three month in operation, she requested a loan from a government program known as the Poverty Alleviation Programme (PAP), which was giving start-up loans to entrepreneurs then. She was given a loan of USD171 which she used to stock a variety of household items commonly bought by residents in the area. The business grew. After one year, she paid back the loan and received another loan of USD28 from Feed The Children Uganda in December 1999. She has become an expert in using loans to expand her business.

Her business generates weekly sales of about USD114, and she anticipates it will grow further. She borrowed USD285 from Pearl Microfinance and paid it very well. Kyebando is an up-and-coming residential area. Milly has noticed two hardware shops in the area. She wants to start selling cement in addition to the retail shop.

Milly is married and has five children who are all in school. She has a supportive husband who pays school fees for all the children. The couple has been able to build a residential house where they are staying.

loans.use: Milly wants to buy 15 bags of cement as well as sugar and rice for the retail shop.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. started her business in 2000 after learning for 3 years. She is 48 years old, married with 6 children, and lives in Benin City. She is requesting a loan of $800 to buy more goats for sale. She has been with LAPO for 2 years and she is the Leader of her Group in LAPO.

loans.use: To buy more goats to sell

loans.name: Alicia

texts.es:
Alicia is a mother and a hard-working woman who is looking to forge a better future for her three cherished children. For this reason five years ago she decided to move to Hualhuas. Her husband is a native of that region and the decided to open a lodging area. They saw that this type of enterprise was in demand as the area was very touristy and busy. Now the entire family contributes to running and caring for the business. Thanks to the team-oriented business, harmony and cooperation are maintained between family members. Alicia watches with satisfaction the improvement of her home. In order to fulfill every request of the people who visit her city, Alicia has put in motion a plan so that every person this month that desires a room will have one. She desires to move forward with her plans. She is motivated by the immense love and commitment of her family. Let’s support Alicia to fulfill her noble desires.

Translated from Spanish by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer.

Alicia, es una madre y a la vez una mujer emprendedora que está buscando forjar un mejor futuro para sus tres queridos hijos y es por esta razón que hace cinco años decidió radicar a Hualhuas debido a que su esposo es natural de ese lugar y decidieron aperturar un negocio de hospedajes ante la necesidad que percibieron por haberse convertido este lugar en un espacio muy turístico y visitado.Ahora toda la familia participa de la administración y atención de este negocio familiar y gracias a este desempeño en equipo se mantiene la armonía y cooperación de todos sus miembros.Alicia ve con satisfacción el sostenimiento de la economía de su hogar y para cumplir con cada uno de los requerimientos de las personas que visitan su ciudad ha puesto en marcha un plan a fin de que en este mes todos y cada una de las posibles solicitudes puedan ser cubiertas. Desea seguir adelante con sus planes motivada por el inmenso amor y compromiso de su familia.Apoyemos a Alicia a seguir adelante con estos nobles deseos.

loans.use: Increase lodging space and purchase of items for her project

loans.name: Ni Wayan Sendel

texts.id:
Ni Wayan Sendel originated from the village of Manistutu. A large portion the residents’ source of income is from farming. Ni Wayan Sendel and husband, Ketut Sukra, livelihood is from compatible crop rotation. Ni Wayan Sendel borrowed from Dinari Rp. 3.000.000,- (about USD320). This funding will be used to purchase corn seeds and pay for cultivation. Also since it is the rainy season all farmers cultivate compatible crop in the rice fields. Ni Wayan Sendel buys corn seeds Rp. 1.000.000,- (about USD100) for the 2 hectare land. Ni Wayan Sendel and husband do not usually farm the whole plot of land. Ni Wayan Sendel use day labor to plant and maintain the cornfields. Commencing from plowing the land, then planting the corn seeds. When the corn seeds sprout and removing weeds around them. Finally fertilizing them. Until harvest, Ni Wayan Sendel incur labor Rp. 1.500.000,- (USD160). Ni Wayan Sendel is borrowing Rp. 3.000.000,- (USD320), also creates jobs for those who are not able. Gross revenue from the cornfield of Rp. 4.000.000,- (USD425). The net income for Ni Wayan Sendel and husband will be Rp. 1.500.000,- (USD160) per harvest over a period of 3 months.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Wayan Sendel berasal dari Desa Manistutu . Sebagian besar mata pencaharian penduduk Manistutu adalah sebagai petani. Ni Wayan Sendel dan suaminya, Ketut Sukra, hidup dari hasil bercocok tanam. Ni Wayan Sendel meminjam modal dari Dinari sebesar Rp.3.000.000,-. Modal ini akan digunakan untuk membeli bibit jagung dan biaya pemeliharaannya. Apalagi sekarang musim penghujan semua petani beramai-ramai bercocok tanam di sawah. Ni Wayan Sendel membeli bibit jagung Rp.1.000.000,- untuk 2 hektar tanahnya. Ni Wayan Sendel dan suaminya tidak bisa mengerjakan semua kebunnya. Ni Wayan Sendel mencari buruh harian untuk menanami juga memelihara kebun jagungnya. Mulai dari mengolah tanahnya biar gembur , setelah itu baru menanaminya dengan bibit jagung. Setelah tumbuh bibit jagungnya lagi digemburkan sambil mencabuti rumput yang tumbuh disekelilingnya. Terakhir baru memberi pupuk . Sampai panen Ni Wayan Sendel menghabiskan biaya buruh Rp.1.500.000,-. Ni Wayan Sendel senang dengan pinjaman Rp. 3.000.000,- bisa juga membuka lapangan pekerjaan bagi orang yang tidak mampu. Adapun pendapatan kotor dari hasil kebun jagungnya Rp.4.000.000,-. Jadi keuntungan bersih yang didapat Ni Wayan Sendel dan Suaminya adalah Rp.1.500.000,- per panen selama masa pemeliharaan 3 bulan.

loans.use: Purchase corn seeds and pay for labor (Membeli bibit jagung dan biaya pekerja)

loans.name: Antonio Tobias

texts.es:
Antonio M. is a very responsible gentleman who repairs shoes for a living at the local Leon area.

His business is widely visited by many because he is capable of fixing shoes. He offers his clients a high quality service.

Antonio M. has the urgency to purchase materials to repair these shoes (leather, sand paper, thread and glue). For this reason he goes to Ceprodel in order to get the necessary credit that will allow him repair shoes and offer the best quality out there.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

Antonio M. es un caballero muy responsable que se dedica a la reparación de zapatos en las afueras del mercado central del departamento de León.

Su negocio se caracteriza por ser muy visitado debido a que el señor M. posee mucha habilidad en la reparación de los zapatos y por esto es que se prepara para recibir a sus clientes y brindarles un servicio de alta calidad.

Una necesidad que atraviesa el señor Antonio M. es la urgencia de la compra de los productos para la reparación de los zapatos (cuero, lija, pega e hilo) y por esta razón acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiado con créditos que le permitan adquirir estos materiales para continuar siendo el mejor zapatero de su localidad.

loans.use: Purchase materials needed to repair shoes

loans.name: Dina's Group

texts.en:
Dina, Neomi, and Rosa have been members of the community bank Manantial for less than one year. They were invited to join the bank by friends and colleagues. Through the community bank they have learned responsibility, the importance of saving, money management, and solidarity.

Dina is a 25 year old student studying elementary education at the local university. She sells cosmetics and other beauty products on order to help pay for school. She uses catalogues from companies such as Avon to take orders for her friends and family.

Neomi is 42 years old, married and has three children. Neomi joined the bank in order to take advantage of the interest earning savings account. She takes out small loans in order to help other family members.

Rosa is 22 years old, married and has one young child. She is studying elementary education. In order to help pay for school, Rosa works with a friend selling soft drinks and beer. She does not like this business, and with her loan she will open a store selling clothing.

Dina, Neomi, and Rosa need $675, which they will use to buy beauty products, support a family member, and start selling clothing.

Their dreams are to finish school, find good jobs, and build a house.

loans.use: To buy beauty products, support a family member, and start selling clothing

loans.name: Walid

texts.en: Walid is 41 years old and is a father of 4. He works and lives with his family in southern Lebanon, in Saida. Walid sells fruits and vegetables. This is the third time he has applied for a loan through A. Majmoua. Walid is planning to buy a pick-up truck to develop his business.

loans.use: to buy a pick-up truck

loans.name: Doto

texts.en:
Doto is 32 years old, married, with two children, ages 10 and 4. Doto started selling clothes in 2005, and everyday she works from 7am to 8pm at her business. She can earn a monthly profit of about $350 from her sales.

In the past, Doto has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Mansa

texts.en:
Mansa T. is married, but her husband's income from his job as a tailor is not sufficient for Mansa and her two children. Mansa sells "Kenkey", a local dish that is very popular. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
Graciela is a shopkeeper selling soft drinks and groceries (such as rice, sugar, sweets, bread, etc.). She does not have sufficient capital since she is a single woman without a husband, therefore she needs a loan in order to buy merchandise and generate more income.

Her home is in the Irpavi II district of La Paz. She lives in a rental. This is the first time she has requested a loan from Impro. Her work and self-improvement give her the opportunity of this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

Graciela es comerciante y vende refrescos y abarrotes (productos como arroz, azucar, dulces,pan, etc); no cuenta con suficiente capital ya que es persona sola y no tiene esposo, por lo cual requiere el crédito con el objetivo de comprar mercadería y generar mas ingresos. Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona Irpavi II de la ciudad de La Paz. Vive en alquiler Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, Su trabajo y las ganas de superación le permiten acceder a este crédito.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for her grocery store (soft drinks, sweets, rice, bread, sugar, etc.)

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora has been selling milk in Arusha since 2001. She is married and has four children, ages 5, 11, 18, and 22. She also has two dependents in her care: a 5-year-old and an 11-year-old. She works daily from 6:00am to 6:00pm and is able to earn a profit of approximately $30 each month.

Flora has taken out two previous loans from BRAC Tanzania with which she bought more cows. She paid both back successfully and on time. She now wants to take out this loan so that she can buy more food for her animals. By feeding them better, they will hopefully produce more milk and give her more to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food for her cows.

loans.name: Tienkadi (La Vérité Est Bonne) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tienkadi est composé de femmes mariées vivant en générale dans des foyers polygames avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 3 enfants et résidant dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de  Sikasso (troisième région économique du Mali).
Ces femmes exercent le commerce de savons (de toilette, de lessive de fabrication locale) des condiments alimentaires et  autres articles. Unies par des liens de parenté et d’alliance, les femmes du groupe décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe.
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 6 cartons de savons et une importante quantité de condiments alimentaires. Elles s’approvisionnent généralement au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso (quelques fois à Bamako et au Burkina Faso) auprès des grossistes attitrés et dans les localités environnantes auprès de paysans producteurs de  légumineuses (tel les choux, piments, oignons). Ensuite elles viennent  revendre ces articles dans les quartiers de façon ambulante, dans les marchés avec une place fixe sous des hangars. Les ventes sont en majorité au comptant et quelques fois à crédit. La clientèle est composée essentiellement  des femmes .
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 17.500FCFA, lequel sera reinvesti dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The Tienkado group is composed of married women generally living in polygamous households in the Hamdallaye area of the city of Sikasso (third largest economic region of Mali) and are on average 35 years old and have 3 children. These women buy and sell soaps (locally made body soap and laundry soap), food condiments and other items. United by blood and marriage relationships, the women in the group decided to be involved with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and they are currently on their first loan from the group. With this loan they plan on purchasing 6 boxes of soap and a large quantity of food condiments. They generally get supplies from the large market in the city of Sikasso (also sometimes from Bamako and in Burkina Faso) from bulk sellers and in surrounding areas from rural producers of vegetables (such as cabbage, peppers, onions). Then they re-sell these items in the neighborhoods in a mobile way (door to door) or in the markets with a fixed spot under hangars. Sales are generally in cash and sometimes for credit. Their customers are essentially women. They hope to earn a monthly profit of 17,500 FCFA (approximately $ 38) which would be reinvested into their activities.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing soaps and food condiments

loans.name: Martha Alejandra

texts.es: La señora Martha  Alejandra S. C. tiene 2 hijos los cuales  están  en escuelas privadas. Uno de ellos cursa  preescolar pero le cobran la mitad de la colegiatura ya que ella trabaja ahí, el  hijo mayor esta en preparatoria  pero acostumbra pagar por adelantado por que en esta escuela da un descuento de cierto porcentaje al pagar con anticipación. Es su segundo crédito y estamos convencidos que es un persona puntual para efectuar otro préstamo. Pero Alejandra no cuenta con tal cantidad ella vino a nuestras instalaciones solicitando 275 dólares. Ella trabaja en una escuela de cocinera este lugar también maneja guardería ,su esposo se dedica a hacer platillos de comida.
texts.en:
Martha Alejandra has two children in private school. One is in preschool, but half the cost is covered because she works there. Her oldest son is in preparatory school, and she tries to pay the tuition in advance because the school gives a discount for those payments. But she can not make such a payment currently, so she came to our institution requesting a loan of $275. She works at a cooking school that also runs a daycare center. Her husband makes a living making and selling meals. This is her second loan, and we are convinced that she is a person who can timely repay another line of credit.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Educational expenses

loans.name: Adriana

texts.es:
Adriana inicio el negocio hace poco mas de 3 años ya que necesitaban dinero para los gastos de las casa y para que a sus hijos no les faltara nada. Empezó ayudándole a vender productos naturales a una conocida pero al poco tiempo decidió trabajar por su cuenta y actualmente ya tiene su cartera de clientes.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $775 que pagara en 6 meses para invertir en mercancía y así lograr sacar adelante a su familia ya que su esposo se encuentra desempleado.
texts.en:
Adriana started her business more than 3 years ago because she needed to cover the household expenses and to provide her children so that they would not need anything. She started out by helping a friend to sell natural products but soon she decided to go and work by her own account. Today she has formed a good clientele.

She requires a loan in the amount of $375 US, which will be repaid in a term of 6 months. The funds will be invested in the purchase of merchandise. This will help her take care of her family, especially now that her husband is currently unemployed.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Biviana

texts.es:
Doña Biviana pertenece al Banco Comunal “Espíritu Santo” del centro poblado D. Chimbo del distrito y Provincia D. Yunguyo- Puno. Tiene 64 años D. edad, asistió al Programa D. Alfabetización durante 01 año, es casada y madre D. 5 hijos. Biviana vive con una D. sus nietas quien siempre la acompaña. Trabaja aproximadamente 7 años con el Banco. Con el  primer préstamo recibido D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles decidió invertir en la crianza D. animales menores como ovejas, chanchitos, negocio que inicio cuando entro al Banco y en el que trabaja junto a su esposo.

Con el ultimo préstamo que recibirá D. S/: 2500.00 nuevos soles el cual será pagado en 5 cuotas comprara 01 vaca y forraje para engorD..

Su deseo es mejorar sus ganancias y así incrementar su  capital.
texts.en:
Ms Biviana belongs to the community bank "Espíritu Santo" of Chimbo in the district and province of Yunguyo-Puno. She is 64 years old and attended the Literacy Program for a year. She is married and the mother of 5 children. Biviana lives with one of her granddaughters, who is always by her siD.. She has been a member of the community bank for approximately 7 years. She decided to invest her first loan of S/. 300.00 nuevos soles ($100 USD) in breeding small animals such as sheep and pigs, a business she started when she joined the bank and at which she works with her husband. She will use this loan of S/: 2500.00 nuevos soles ($825 USD) to buy a cow for fattening up, as well as fodder. She will repay the loan in 5 installments. Her wish is to improve her earnings and thus increase her capital.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 1 cow and fodder to fatten it up.

loans.name: Rubina Aziz M.shafiq Group

texts.en:
Rubina aziz baji is a 29 year old lady and resides in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine places.  Most people come to this city to visit the shrine places to make wishes. 

Rubina baji owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 5 years.  She is the mother of eight children: six daughters and two sons.  None of her children go to school.  Her husband is a fruit seller by profession, and has 4 years of experience.  

Rubina baji herself has a decorative embroidery business.  She also teaches the girls in her community how to embroider dresses.  She has been making embroidered dresses for the past 4 years.  She does this work to support her husband in meeting the financial expenses of the house.  

She has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now she is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her husband’s fruit selling business. 
 
She is a group leader of a few more members of her community.  Sakina baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes selling business.  Razia baji wants a loan to buy tools for her jewelry making business.  Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  Kaniz Fatima baji wants a loan to buy stamp papers to resell. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to resell

loans.name: Anna S.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 52-year-old Anna M. from Tukuyu. She is widow with six children between the ages of 18 and 37. She is also responsible for supporting two other people because they are orphans. Anna has made a living running a clothes shop since 1997.

She works at this business for 9-12 hours a day, 6 days a week, with help from her children. Anna currently earns about $100 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $375 to buy more clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of items she has for sale. Anna  thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more clothes in bulk

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Thirty-year-old Regina O. is the mother of five children, two boys and three girls, one of whom has not yet begun school. She lives with the family in Koforidua, a small farming and commercial town not far from Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. Her husband owns a provisions shop.

Most of the women in the community deal in bananas and other fruits, as does Regina, who buys bananas from the nearby villages, stores them for ripening, and then sells them to retailers in the local market as well as other nearby venues.

Regina has been in business for ten years, and it is her dream to save enough money to support her husband in taking care of the family. She is therefore requesting a loan to procure bananas in bulk so as to maximize her profit margin.

loans.use: To procure bananas in bulk.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria B. is in the business of selling fresh fish at the market and is requesting a loan to expand her business.  Victoria is 27 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her fresh fish business

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric F. is 33 years old, married, and a father with two children. His children are in school.  Eric has sold frozen foods in the local market in Dome for 2 years now. He is very supportive at home, especially in the upbringing of his children. 

However, he says income from the business is very low because he pays high rent on the store he operates from and the electricity cost is also high as he shares his power with another shop nearby. He would like to use the loan to buy more cartons of frozen foods to enable him to raise enough income to build a permanent store for himself. He also wants the loan to buy items to stock his inventory before the Easter season. Eric belongs to a village bank called ‘Sunkwa,’ which means ‘Pray for Life’. He hopes to receive 800 GHS to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy frozen foods

loans.name: Raúl

texts.es:
El señor Raúl S. tiene ya más de diez años dedicándose a la reparación de vehículos particulares. Este es el ingreso de su familia y con el cual les está pagando los estudias a sus tres hijos.
Pero a su taller le está haciendo falta un equipo nuevo de mecánico mas moderno y de mejor calidad, en esté momento no tiene el dinero necesario para invertir en la compra de equipo, portal motivo está solicitando un préstamo para comprar el equipo y así darles el mejor servicio a los vehículos de su clientes.
texts.en:
Raul S. has been repairing vehicles for more than 10 years, which provides the income for his family and the means for which he pays the school bills for his children. However, his workshop is lacking a new piece of equipment that is more modren and of better quality than what he currently has. At this time, he does not have enough money to invest in this equipment, which is the motive for applying for this loan so that he can acquire this equipment and provide a better service to his clients.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase equipment for his auto repair shop.

loans.name: Delicia

texts.es: Delicia es una mujer muy trabajadora, ya que al tener la responsabilidad de velar por el bienestar de sus cuatro hijas tuvo que esforzarse para salir adelante, y a pesar de vivir en una casa alquilada trata siempre de brindar a sus hijas las mejores comodidades posibles. Desde muy joven se desempeñó en múltiples actividades, pero actualmente se dedica a brindar servicio de limpieza de casas, y gracias a que la mayoría de personas no cuentan con tiempo para atender sus roles domésticos, Delicia tiene la oportunidad de trabajo. Cada día, empieza su trabajo a las seis de la mañana, hasta el medio día, hora en que regresa a casa para atender sus a sus hijas. Este trabajo es muy rentable, y solo trabaja medio día, además desea incursionar en el rubro textil, pues tiene el don de realizar trabajos de bordados y de alta costura, habilidades que la llevarán pronto a contar con un negocio propio. Delicia es cliente de MFP más 5 años, este es su octavo préstamo, y en el tiempo de permanencia en su grupo puede manifestar que el trabajo es muy organizado, con algunas presiones, lo cual es bueno porque se enseña a las señoras a ser responsables en sus pagos. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de materiales para iniciar su negocio de costura, con la fe de que alcance sus metas con éxito.
texts.en:
Delicia is a hard-working woman. Since she is responsible for the welfare of her four daughters, she had to strive to succeed. Despite living in a rented house, she always tries to give her daughters the best comfort possible. Since she was very young, she got started in many activities, but now works cleaning house. Because most people do not have time to attend to their domestic roles, Delicia has the opportunity to work. Each day she begins her work at six o'clock until noon, then returns home to attend to her daughters. This work is very profitable, and she only works half days. She also wants to break into the textile field and has a gift working with high quality embroidery and sewing and will soon have her own business. Delicia is a client of MFP for over 5 years, this is her eighth loan, and during the time in her group she showed that her work is highly organized, with some pressure, which is good because it teaches the ladies to be responsible in their payments. The money requested is to purchase materials to start her sewing business, with the faith to reach her goals successfully.

Translated from Spanish by Tim Hassett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to establish a sewing shop

loans.name: Mahfirat

texts.ru: Махфират - женщина, которая торгует на рынке Паншанбе нижнем женским бельём. Она замужем , имеет двоих взрослых детей. По мимо нижнего белья она имеет ассортимент женской  и мужской одежды.Махфират хочет получив следующий кредит съездить за товаром в Истаравшан и привести летний ассортимент товаров.Махфират выражает свою благодарность инвесторам за сотрудничество и своевременное финансирование.
texts.en:
Mahfirat sells women’s undergarments at the Panshanbe market. She is married and has two grown children. Besides undergarments, she also has an assortment of women’s and men’s clothing. Mahfirat wants obtain this loan in order to bring a summer goods assortment from Istaravshan. Mahfirat expresses her gratitude to investors for collaboration and timely financing.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To obtain an assortment of summer merchandise

loans.name: Milka

texts.es:
MILKA S. D., pertenece al Banco Comunal “CARMEN CABREJOS” con domicilio en el Jr. Comandante espinar N° 646 del distrito D. Callería, tiene 39 años, 03 hijos, y su esposo tiene trabajo como conductor D. una moto taxi (Transportista).

Tenía un negocio D. venta productos D. bisutería y la primera vez obtuvo un préstamo D. S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, hace 2 años, con él, compro sus productos (bisuteria) que luego los vendió a sus vecinos.

Ahora amplio su negocio y además venD. ropas como; blusas, pantalones, toallas, colchas, carteras, etc. 
Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,000.00 Nuevos Soles, invertirá en la compra D. mas mercaderías (ropa) y parte del dinero lo usara para comprar repuestos D. su moto taxi.

En el poco tiempo que esta con Manuela Ramos se siente contenta, por la ayuda que da a las mujeres para salir adelante, ayudar a su esposo e hijos, y en la economía del hogar.
texts.en:
Milka S. D. is a member of the community bank “CARMEN CABREJOS”. She lives at #646, Comandante Espinar Street in the district of Callería. She is 39 years old and has three children. Her husband works as a driver of a motorbike taxi. Milka used to have a business selling imitation jewellery only. The first time she obtained a loan of S/.300 with her husband, two years ago, she bought jewellery which she sold to her neighbours. Now her business has grown; she also sells clothing such as blouses and pants, as wells as towels, bedspreads, purses etc. She will use part of the S/.1,000 loan to buy more merchandise (clothing), and part of it will also go to the purchase of spare parts for the motorbike taxi. In the short time that she has been with Kiva partner, Manuela Ramos, she has felt happy because of the help that the organisation offers to women who want to get ahead, or to help their husbands and children, and to contribute to the family finances.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing. To buy spare parts for a motorbike taxi

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience A. is married and has 2 children. She has received schooling through senior high. Patience sells soft drinks such as Fanta, Sprite Coca-Cola and assorted fruit drinks at Melcom in Hohoe, which she has done since 1998. Patience will use the loan to purchase more of the assorted soft drinks and revive her salon as well. With the new profits from her expanded business, Patience plans to reinvest into the business.

loans.use: To buy drinks for resale and to invest in salon

loans.name: Rat

texts.en:
Mr. Rat C., 52, has three children: two sons and one daughter. One of his sons has full-time employment in a factory, and another one attends school. The daughter is married, but lives in the family home. The family lives along National Road number two about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Rat has been driving a motor-taxi in Phnom Penh for 20 years. He is asking for his first loan of $600 to fill up the land behind his house and purchase a motorbike for his son-in-law to replace the old one.

loans.use: To fill up the land behind his house and purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Keita Nelly

texts.es:
Keita es socia del Banco Comunal Confianza.
Keita es conviviente, tiene 28 años y 3 hijos, Keita viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde vende papa, panes y de las ferias compra cereales que luego procesa en harina, producto que vende en la ciudad de Pisco.
Keita necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cebada.
Los sueños de Keita son ahorrar para comprar un terreno.
texts.en:
Keita is a member of the communal bank group “Confianza” (Trust). She is 28 years old, in a common law marriage, and has 3 children. She travels to the different markets in the region selling potatoes and bread. While at the markets, she buys grain for processing into flour, which she then sells in the city of Pisco.

Keita needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy barley. She dreams of saving enough money to purchase a plot of land.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase barley

loans.name: Afi Mama

texts.fr:
Cette dame exerce depuis 2001 la vente de produits alimentaires au grand marché de Lomé, grâce à son dynamisme et son sens des affaires. Elle sollicite de WAGES un prêt lui permettant d’acheter 02 cartons de pâte alimentaire, 03 bidons d’huile, 05 sacs de riz, 04 cartons de vins et divers produits
elle est célibataire sans enfants, c'est avec le revenu de son commerce qu'elle subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
Thanks to her dynamism and her business sense, this woman started her business in 2001, selling food products in the big market in Lomé. She is asking the micro-finance organization WAGES for a loan which will enable her to purchase 2 cartons of pasta, 3 canisters of oil, 5 sacks of rice, 4 cartons of wine and various other products.

She is single and without children. It's with the revenues from her business that she is able to help pay for the needs of her family.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Benedicto

texts.es:
Benedicto tiene 51 años, vive en pareja con Mirta de 49 años de edad. De la unión de  ambos han nacido 3 hijas de 21, 18 y 13 años de edad respectivamente.
Benedicto es un sacrificado hombre que trabajó varios años en  la Argentina, desempeñándose como constructor de obras. Trabajó  como casi 20 años, allí conoció a la que hoy día es su actual pareja y del dinero que pudo ahorrar durante ese tiempo vino a quedarse ya en su país, que es el Paraguay. 
Una vez instalados en  su país de origen, lograron emprender juntos su propio negocio. Actualmente la señora posee una pequeña despensa en su domicilio y  Benedicto tiene una parada de taxi en  Itá, ciudad de la cual ambos son oriundos. 
Gracias a su esfuerzo y la ayuda de su pareja hoy en día  ya cuenta con dos vehículos que emplea en dicha actividad. 

Comenta  Benedicto que se siente muy orgulloso del trabajo y de su compañera por el apoyo constante que le brinda. 

En esta oportunidad solicita el préstamo para la compra de cubiertas y algunas otras cosas como baterías para su vehículo de manera a ponerlo a punto y así brindar un mejor servicio a sus numerosos pasajeros.
texts.en:
Benedicto is 51. He lives with his partner, Mirta, who is 49. They have three children ages 21, 18, and 13. Benedicto is a sacrificing man who worked various years in Argentina. He worked in construction for almost 20 years, and he met Mirta there. With the money he was able to save during that time, he was able to return to his country, Paraguay, to stay. Once back in his country, together they were able to start their own business. She currently has a small store in her home. Benedicto has a taxi service in Itá, the city they are both from. Thanks to his effort and help from Mirta, he now has two cars, which are used in the taxi service. He feels very proud of his work and of Mirta for the help she constantly gives him. He is asking for a loan to buy tires and other things like batteries for his vehicle. He will tune up his vehicle and then be able to offer better service to his numerous passengers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tires, batteries and others

loans.name: La Union Lo Vecino 1, 2, & 3 Group

texts.en:
Ramon C. R. is a borrower from the city of San Pedro de Macoris in the Dominican Republic. He is the coordinator for his group of borrowers, and his story represents similar businesses run by others in his group. Ramon is 35 years old, and has an 8 year old son, a 3 year old daughter, and a brand new baby girl who is just one month old. Ramon lives with his children in a home he rents on the bottom floor of his building. He also rents space for his shop in the same building.

Ramon is an electrician who builds inverters for his community. He has run his own business for the last four years, and hopes to continue expanding in the future. Power outages, humidity, and older electronics mean that his skills as an electrician are needed frequently. With this loan, Ramon hopes to build 20 electronic inverters that he can sell to his customers. This will increase his profit margin and allow him to expand his business.

In the past, Ramon's only loan options charged him huge amounts, as much as 20% per week. These loans were not feasible for him, but now through Esperanza his loans have become extremely helpful. In the future, he hopes to expand his business by hiring an employee and expanding his business to the sales of batteries and other electronics. This is Ramon's second loan through Esperanza, and he hopes that it will not be his last.

loans.use: To construct 20 more inverters.

loans.name: Benita Lorena

texts.es:
En el mercado el Bisne de la ciudad de Chinandega, la señora Benita Lorena R. se ha destacado por ser comerciante de comida elaborada por ella misma y ofreciéndola a los clientes que visitan el mercado.

Por esta razón es que la señora Benita R. ha acudido a solicitar el crédito ya que está interesada en desarrollar su negocio y requiere para esto la compra de la materia prima para elaborar todos los tipos de alimentos y así venderlos a sus clientes que muy seguramente los compraran porque ella los elabora muy gustosos.

loans.use: Compra de materia prima para elaborar alimentos

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas is 45 years old and married with three children. She sells provisions. She lives in Benin City, Edo State. She hopes for a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Zamir

texts.en:
Zamir Ahmad is the son of D. M.. He lives in Jalalabad city. He is a young boy. Even though he is so young, he still feels lots of responsibilities towards his family members. He lives in a family of 7 members, including his father and mother. He is the oldest son in his family. 

Zamir has a sandals shop where he sells different kinds of sandals. He wants to take an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for the purpose of purchasing more and good quality materials for his shop. In fact, his main purpose is to attract more clients and to purchase items of in high demand in his market. He hopes to develop his business after taking the loan and to bring about changes in his business. He is confident that he will repay his loan on time and will join to take a second cycle loan after the full repayment of first cycle loan. He would like to extend his gratitude to all the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Jamileh

texts.en: Jamileh is a widowed mother of three children. She has been working as a home-based tailor since 1994 to earn income for her family. Today, Jamileh is requesting a loan of $1,000 to renovate her sewing machine to meet the demand of her clients and produce more tailoring products.

loans.use: To renovate her sewing machine

loans.name: Orlando

texts.en:
Orlando S. is from the town of Ilagan. He is 34 years old, married and has two school-aged children.  Orlando owns and operates a business raising crops, mainly planting and harvesting rice.

In 2007, Orlando joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Orlando has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI to purchase seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.

Orlando is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase more seeds, seedlings and young crops.  He plans to use the additional revenue generated to support his family. 
---------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.es:
La señora Marcelina es socia del Banco Comunal “San Juan”, en el distrito y provincia D. Yunguyo, departamento D. Puno. Ella tiene 60 años D. edad, es casada y tiene 3 hijos. Estudiò primaria completa y se dedica a la compra y venta D. cereales.
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace 2 años atrás y su primer préstamo fue D.  S/.500.00 nuevos soles el mismo que le sirvió para la compra D. cañihua, cebada, habas, quinua, etc.
Ella solicitará un préstamo D. S/.1,500.00 nuevos soles con los que comprarà dos toros y harà crecer su negocio.
Su deseo para el futuro es que sus hijos sean profesionales y que cada uno tenga su casa propia.
Lo que màs le gusta D. su organización es el ahorro y las reuniones que hay con las socias.
texts.en:
Marcelina is a member of the community bank San Juan in Yunguyo, Puno. Marcelina is 60 years old, married and has three children. She has an elementary school education and buys and sells cereal grains for a living. Marcelina has been working with the Manuela Ramos movement for two years. She used her first loan to purchase kaniwa, barley, beans, quinoa, etc. This time around, she will use her loan to buy two bulls and expand her business. Her hope for the future is that her children can become professionals and own their own homes. Her favourite aspects of community bank membership are having the chance to build her savings and being able to meet with other members.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying two bulls

loans.name: María Fernanda

texts.es:
En el Banco Comunal Sucre se reúne en Montecristi en este sitio podemos encontrar los más finos y elegantes sombreros de paja toquilla de la zona, los artesanos también son expertos en elaborar muebles y adornos para el hogar en toquilla. 


Maria Fernanda es nacida de Montecristi,  vive con su esposo  de profesión chofer y su hijo, su casa es propia. Nuestra socia es comerciante ambulante desde hace 8 años vende sabanas, cortinas, edredones, toldos y ropa en general, anteriormente   vendía joyas y algunos clientes le quedaron mal  por eso decidió empezar con el negocio de ropa,  para abastecerse ella  viaja a Guayaquil a comprar su mercadería, se inició con 400 dólares pero poco a poco ha ido incrementando su negocio gracias a los créditos recibidos de la Fundación.

Con este nuevo préstamo va a adquirir  sabanas para cumplir con varios  pedidos pendientes de sus clientes.
texts.en:
The Sucre Community Bank meets in the town of Montecristi, where we can find the most elegant and carefully made Panama hats in the area. The craftsmen are also experts in making furniture and home decor out of this straw. Maria Fernanda was born in Montecristi, where she lives with her husband (a driver) and her son in her own house. She has been a traveling sales woman for 8 years, selling sheets, curtains, comforters, canopies, and clothing. She previously sold jewelry, but some customers cheated her, so she decided to establish her clothing business. For merchandise she travels to Guayaquil. She started her business with $400 but has gradually grown it thanks to loans from the Foundation. With this next loan, she will buy sheets, to fulfill pending customer orders.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheets

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhen Menh Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhen M. is 44 years old. She is the president of a village bank that consists of 18 people who live in TrapE. Phlong Village in Takeo Province. All the members will be using their loans to support their families and for different purpose. 

Mrs. Sokhen M. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Samaiy Oun, is a teacher in the local village. Even though they try to work hard in their businesses, they still cannot support their family members. 

Thus, Mrs. Sokhen M. wants to start a new business to improve their living conditions. She has decided to ask for a loan to buy pigs to breed. She will use the rest of the loan to buy equipment and supplies to construct a pigpen. 

Mrs. Sokhen M. is the mother of four children. One of her children is an employee in a garment factory, one does housework, and the other two are students in the local school. All of the members of the village bank are shown in the photo, but some of thE. are blocked.

loans.use: To buy pigs to breed and supplies to build a pigpen

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase food ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Rukayat

texts.en:
Rukayat has a good relationship with LAPO. She sells daily from 7 am to 7 pm. She sells groceries ranging from toothpaste to noodles. She has been in this business for a long time. She uses her experience in business to attract and retain more customers. 

She hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She would like to own a shopping mall in the future. Rukayat is 30 years old and married with two children. Her eldest child is seven years old while the youngest is three years old. Her children are making progress in school. Her husband sells tires and he also supports the home. 

Rukayat says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Preciosa

texts.en:
Despite the challenges she faces every day because of being poor, Preciosa remains energetic and is enjoying a simple life together with her husband and three children, whose ages range from 5 to 10 years old. Her heart is filled with dreams and inspiration because of the love and support she receives from her family. It keeps her moving on and to achieving the vision of success beyond poverty.

With the use of her tribike (bicycle with a sidecar), at times together with her children and husband, Preciosa roams around the entire village to buy junk and scrap. A large volume of this will be sold to the owner of a huge junk shop. Therefore she is requesting a loan which will be used to finance the growth of her scrap/junk buy-and-sell business.

Preciosa’s kind of business is friendly to the environment since it helps people manage their garbage well by separating it and selling that which is recyclable. Aside from providing income to her family, her business can also provide income to people and children in their village and around the town.

Through her business, Preciosa and her husband are happy to collect junk from all over the town and make money from it.

loans.use: To purchase more junk and recyclable items to sell

loans.name: Gisèle

texts.fr: Z. Gisèle est née le 04 Mai 1984 et vit depuis 8 ans au quartier Djassin, dans le troisième arrondissement de Porto-Novo au Bénin. Mariée à AFATON Marius, Gisèle est mère d'un enfant. La famille vit ensemble et le couple assure les différentes charges familiales. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Gisèle mène comme activité, la vente de vêtements, de parfums et aussi de glacières de façon ambulante. Gisèle s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Gisèle exerce cette activité depuis 10 ans et a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits de ALIDé. Gisèle a bien remboursé les trois crédits qu'elle avait obtenu. Gisèle aimerait augmenter le volume de son activité et mieux satisfaire toutes les demandes de sa clientèle. Mais Gisèle ne réunit pas les moyens financiers nécessaires pour y arriver. C'est la raison pour laquelle Gisèle sollicite un quatrième prêt de ALIDé, afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Gisèle Z. was born on May 4, 1984. She has been living for eight years in the neighborhood of Djassin, the third arrondissement [municipal district] of Porto-Novo in Benin. Gisèle is married to Marius Afaton and is the mother of one child. The family lives together and the couple provides for the different needs of the family. To meet her needs, Gisèle’s business activity is the door-to-door sale of clothing, perfumes and also of iceboxes. She gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been practicing this activity for 10 years and has already received three loans from ALIDé. She has fully reimbursed the three loans she received. Gisèle would like to increase the volume of her activity to better meet all the demands of her customers. However she cannot bring together the necessary financial means to succeed. For this reason, she is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé in order to increase her working capital.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing and iceboxes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Miyansarkhon

texts.en:
Miyansarkhon, together with her partner, has a small business selling construction supplies in their store which has lately been expanded. Their store is filled with attractive, reasonably priced items that appeal to many customers who are looking to build something like an office, a house, etc. 

Miyansarkhon has been in business for about 4 years. She likes what she sells and has developed a stable enterprise. Currently she has requested a loan to help purchase a new supply of items to sell. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new supplies of items to sell

loans.name: 17 De Agosto Group

texts.es:
Tejido de prendas de vestir como chompas, manoplas y otros es el negocio al cual se dedicaba la señora Julia C. que a sus 65 años sigue generando ingresos, ahora desea cambiar de negocio, tiene planificado vender comida con ayuda de su hija y necesita el préstamo para comprar insumos.
Las demás integrantes tienen variados negocios como la venta de artefactos, joyas, ropa, carne, cosméticos, y refrescos.
Todas necesitan el préstamo para adquirir mercadería, insumos o materia prima. 
Ellas se reúnen cada dos semanas en el Centro Focal Los Andes.
texts.en:
Julia C., 65, knits sweaters, mittens and other items generating income that way but now wants to change occupation. She plans to start selling prepared meals with help from her daughter and needs funds to buy ingredients. The other group members have various businesses like the sale of artifacts, jewelry, clothing, meat, cosmetics and beverages. They all need funds to acquire merchandise, ingredients or raw materials. They meet every two weeks at Los Andes Focal Center.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients.

loans.name: Clarisse

texts.fr: Née en 1986 à Djidja au Bénin, A. Clarisse est mariée à ASSANKPON Gérôme, un chauffeur. Le couple a six enfants à leurs charges, dont deux sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Clarisse et sa famille vivent enssemble au quartier Tchinvié à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, depuis un an. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Clarisse a très peu fréquenté, et a appris ensuite la couture. Clarisse exerce cette activité depuis près de sept ans.  A côté de cette activité, Clarisse  vend des tissus et aussi des produits vivriers à son domicile et à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est au marché de Tchèti au Bénin, que Clarisse achète ses produits. C'est la première fois que Clarisse sollicite un prêt de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer principalement son activité de vente de produits vivriers et de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1986 in Allada in Benin, Clarisse A. is married to Gérôme ASSANKPON, a driver. The couple have six children under their care, all of whom are attending (or have attended) school. For the past year, Clarisse has lived together with her family in the Tchinvié borough of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. The couple share the various household expenses. Clarisse has had very little schooling, and learned sewing thereafter. She has been a seamstress for seven years. As a side business, she also sells clothing fabric and fresh produce from her home and in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. She buys her products at the Tchèti market in Benin. This is the first time Clarisse has requested a loan from ALIDé, with the main objective of strengthening her produce retail business, and to better satisfy customer demand.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing fabric, thread, and fresh produce (sesame, peanuts)

loans.name: Yessica Del Carmen

texts.es:
Yessica del Carmen, tiene 21 años de edad, reside en San Francisco Gotera departamento de Morazán, es soltera vive con su mamá, está estudiando y se dedica a la venta de de antojitos elaborados a base de plano, leche y azúcar.
Desde hace tres años se dedica a la venta de empanadas ( de plano, leche y azúcar), ella las comercializa en su casa y algunas veces a lugares secanos de donde reside, con el dinero que ella obtiene ha logrado mantener su negocio, solventar  gastos de estudios, algunas necesidades personales y familiares.
Yessica es una joven exitosa con su negocio, responsable y alegre, con deseo de superarse por eso ella continua sus estudios a base de su propio esfuerzo, actualmente ella necesita un préstamo para invertirlo en la compra de materiales para la elaboración de sus empanadas, ella compraría (azúcar, plátanos, aceite, leña y gas), esto contribuirá a continuar con su  venta, generar los ingreso para sus estudios y gastos de su familia.
Ella sueña con terminar su tercer año de Bachillerato a distancia (sábados y Domingos recibe clases), diversificar sus productos de antojitos y mejorar así la calidad de vida de ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Yessica del Carmen Gutiérrez F. is 21-years-old and lives in San Francisco Gotera in the department of Morazán. She's single and lives with her mother. She's studying and sells homemade snack foods made out of plantains, milk, and sugar. She's been selling her empanadas (of plantains, milk, and sugar) for three years. She sells them in her house and sometimes in places around where she lives. With the money that she earns she's managed to maintain her business, pay her education expenses, and some personal and familial expenses. Yessica is a successful young businesswoman; she's responsible and cheerful with a desire to excel. For this reason she continues her studies while supporting herself. Currently she needs a loan to invest in the purchase of ingredients for her empanadas. She will buy sugar, plantains, oil, firewood, and gas. This will help her continue her sales and generate income for her studies and the expenses of her family. She dreams of finishing her third year higher-level distance learning (she takes classes on Saturdays and Sundays), diversifying her snack food products, and improving her and her family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Richardson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sugar, plantains, oil, firewood, and gas

loans.name: Phann

texts.en:
Mrs. Phann I., age 29, lives in Mea Neak village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Phart Reach, are farmers who own three hectares of land to cultivate rice for a livI.. Aside from farmI., Mr. Phart Reach is able to earn a small income raisI. ducks and sellI. duck eggs in order to support his family. 

In order to support both these businesses, Mrs. Phann I. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and to buy duck food. 

This couple has four children: two very young and the older two are attendI. the local school. Her husband is pictured in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and duck food

loans.name: 03.06.10 Dien Bien Group

texts.en:
Thu H. T. (48) is a 48-year-old femaL. living in the town of Thanh Hoa.  Thu is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 03.06.10 Dien Bien.

Thu is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, she provides laundry services to local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND ($158) a month from these activities.

In 2009, Thu joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,248,000 VND.  This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business.  

She is now requesting a new loan of 5,310,000 VND which again will be used to invest in expanding her business.  This will be her 2nd loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Thu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  D. T. Lien (49) is a 60-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.


2.  D. T. Ha (50) is a 36-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a service-based business.


3.  N. T. G. Thanh (51) is a 41-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.


4.  N. T. Lan (52) is a 74-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


5.  L. T. Hang (155) is a 25-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


6.  B. T. Tai (53) is a 55-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector operating a fishing business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Thu H. T. (48) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Thu là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 7 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 10- Dien Bien (03.06.10 Dien Bien).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ nói chung cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Thu thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Thu kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2009, Thu đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Thu đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.248.000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.310.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  D. T. Lien (49) là 60 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


2.  D. T. Ha (50) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


3.  N. T. G. Thanh (51) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


4.  N. T. Lan (52) là 74 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.


5.  L. T. Hang (155) là 25 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.


6.  B. T. Tai (53) là 55 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  D. việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of two dairy cows

loans.name: Amanbek

texts.en:
Amanbek S., age 23, operates a transportation business. He began his business in 2007 with a Russian brand car, and he drives between Hosh Agash, a Russian border region, and Ulgii, the center town of Bayan-Ulgiy, twice a week, transporting up to six passengers. He charges transportation fees of 15,000 MNT per passenger. With his business earnings, Amanbek has been able to afford to build a house for himself and his wife. Amanbek hopes to see his business expand and develop over time. 

He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a variety of products in Russia and to re-sell these at retail prices. Primarily, he hopes to be able to afford to purchase a bus for his business. He also needs to devote some of the loan money to his brother's medical expenses in Khazakhstan. 	

Amanbek lives with his wife and parents in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger,' which is a traditional nomadic housing tent. He and his wife were married a year ago and his parents are retired.

loans.use: To purchase a bus for his transportation business

loans.name: Carlos Alberto

texts.es: El Sr. Carlos Alberto C. es originario del caserío Mina La India del municipio de Santa Rosa del peñón. Su negocio consiste en brindar servicio de un molino para moler masa a dichos pobladores donde tiene cuatro años de tener su propio negocio. Es el primer crédito que solicita en Ceprodel para la compra de una máquina de moler carne y así diversificar su servicio y satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Carlos Alberto C. is from the town of Santa Rosa del Peñón’s Mina La Linda settlement. His business consists in offering corn milling services to residents in the area. He has had his own business for four years. This is his first loan with Ceprodel and it will be used to buy a meat grinder in order to diversify his services and meet customer demand.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a meat grinder.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en: Daisy D. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Poblacion, Sibonga, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: livestock and food processing. Her husband Rodrigo D., who is 36 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children who range from 13 to 18 years old. Daisy joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Daisy has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her business so that she can continue to save up for the future and for her children to finish their educations. Daisy D. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Additional capital for business

loans.name: Cenon

texts.en:
Cenon C. is from the village of North Poblacion, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is 37 years old. Cenon is married and has an infant. To make a living, Cenon owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Cenon has been engaged in his business for more than a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Cenon joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cenon is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Cenon from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn J. is from the village of San Luis, Gingoog City. She is 53 years old. Jocelyn is separated from her spouse and has four adult children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a business making and selling a variety of food especially for viands (special dishes) for different meals like pork and chicken adobo and boiled beef spare ribs in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

location.town: San Luis, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Porfirio Damian

texts.es:
PORFIRIO DAMIAN V. R.,Trabaja como Supervisor de Higienista en el mercado Ivan Montenegro, es padre de familia de tres hijos y estos se encuentran en edad escolar, ha trabajado seis prestamo con ceprodel yu estos han sido para el mejoramiento de su casa de habitacion.
el prestamo solicitado es para la compra de materiales de construccion para la construccion de una pared de su casa.
texts.en:
PORFIRIO DAMIAN V. R. works as a Hygienist Supervisor at Iván Montenegro Market.  He is the father of three school aged children.  He has had six previous Ceprodel loans that he’s used for home improvements.

The requested loan is to buy building materials and supplies to erect a wall.

loans.use: To buy building materials and supplies to erect a wall.

loans.name: Carmen Alexandra

texts.es:
Carmen de 33 años, vende artículos y bisutería en un puesto en la calle. Vive con sus dos hijos de 10 y 12 años en una zona urbana caracterizada porque la mayoría de sus habitantes son comerciantes llamada suburbio de Guayaquil. 

Desde que se separo de su esposo ella comenzó a realizar actividades comerciantes para poder mantener a sus hijos en una situación económica estable. Inicio sus ventas vendiendo bisutería y productos personales poco a poco con esfuerzo pudo comprar bisutería de todo tipo hasta que pudo conseguir un puesto en la calle para vender su mercadería. En la actualidad ella realiza su actividad comercial desde las 07h00am hasta las 15h00pm para pasar más tiempo con sus hijos. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar juguetes y artículos navideños ya que por estas épocas se incrementa la demanda. En el futuro quiere mejorar sus ventas para poder comprar una casa.
texts.en:
Carmen is 33 years old.  She sells articles and costume jewelry from a street stall.  She lives with her two children aged 10 and 12 in an urban area which is characterized by the fact that most of its inhabitants are salespeople.  It is called Guayaquil suburb.

Since she separated from her husband, she began selling merchandise as a way to support her children in a stable economic situation.
